Award.AwardTitle: Networked Battery System Management and Control for Active Diagnosis, Observability and Resilient Operation

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Batteries are one of the most critical enabling technologies for achieving clean, efficient and sustainable energy development in the transportation and power sectors. Advanced vehicle and power grid battery systems consist of networked battery modules of diverse types and characteristics. System-level performance can be interrupted or completely disabled by subsystem abnormality. Beyond typical battery management systems (BMS) for individual battery modules, this project will develop a novel resilient battery management system (RBMS) for reliable operations of networked battery systems. This RBMS will be capable of detecting and locating abnormality, prevent them from propagating, and of reconfiguring the battery system for sustained operation. This critical and transformative technology will support electric vehicles for extended battery life, sustain military missions under limited energy resources, and maintain smart electricity grids without interruption. Beyond its direct technological advance in battery characterization, control and management, this project will have significant educational, societal, and economic impact. It will also help advance technology and workforce development in these energy storage and the many associated fields of application. Within this project, the team will integrate findings into battery technology curricula in the existing Electrical-Drive Vehicle Engineering programs at the undergraduate and graduate levels at Wayne State University. Courses and training seminars on advanced battery management systems will be developed for students, engineers, and technicians to enhance workforce training in vehicle electrification, sustainable energy development, and smart grids. The success of this project will help achieve cleaner, more efficient, and more reliable transportation, power grids, and beyond.

Battery abnormality conditions include potential health deterioration indicated by drifting of characterizing variables into unacceptable regions, faults that must be cleared by timely remedy actions, and failures that are not recoverable. Networked battery systems introduce unique and daunting challenges, including sensing limitations for prompt fault diagnosis and localization, fast and accurate joint estimation of state of charge and characterizing parameters, and advanced power electronics for system reconfiguration. Current battery systems and their management do not include such functions. Employing methodologies from discrete event systems, system identification and state estimation, stochastic analysis, and advanced power electronics control, this project will introduce a new RBMS framework for integrated control, active diagnosis, and sustained operation of networked battery systems.
Collaborating with industry leaders in battery technology, electric vehicles, and smart grids, the team will develop a new theory of active network observers, real-time active diagnosis and localization of abnormal conditions, reconfiguration, and adaptive BMS strategies. The proposed methods represent a transformative technology for managing different types of batteries and structures, including new or old batteries, for vehicle and grid applications. The main approaches of this project have some distinctive and novel features: (1) Discrete event system (DES)-based diagnosis strategies and control decisions. By using systematic DES strategies, fast diagnosis and localization of abnormal conditions can be achieved; (2) Real-time battery characterization for module-level diagnosis. A battery's states and parameters will be jointly estimated for characterizing batteries in real time; and (3) Active system reconfiguration to accommodate resilient operation and adaptive battery management systems. Hardware reconfiguration will prevent local abnormality from spreading to other parts of battery systems. The battery management systems then self-adjust to sustain operation under the new configuration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Goals: This project aims to develop new methodologies to address some fundamental challenges in battery networks. Although there have been extensive studies on characterization, estimation, and control on individual batteries, in practical applications batteries must be interconnected and combined to form a networked system. Management of battery networks encounters highly challenging new issues that require development of new methods, algorithms, and tools, beyond traditional paradigms in battery technology. 

Motivated by applications of battery systems in supporting electric vehicles, buses, trains, renewable generators, and power grids, we view a battery network as a system that contains analog inputs such as charge and discharge currents, discrete-event control such as balancing and by-passing switches, and battery network structural reconfiguration; and is subject to multi-facet uncertainties such as unknown state-of-charge, unknown parameters, component faults, cell or module failure, and delays and losses in communications. Consequently, battery networks must be treated as uncertain hybrid systems. Fundamental issues arise, including hybrid controllability, hybrid observability, hybrid optimal battery charge/discharge management, hybrid diagnosis, reliability analysis, among others.   This project has focused on the following critical aspects: (1) Develop new hybrid methods for SOC (state of charge) and SOH (state of health) estimation. (2) Develop new hybrid control methods for SOC management for networked battery systems. (3) Characterize and diagnose networked battery systems. (4) Develop active on-line fault diagnosis in the framework of discrete event systems. (5) Develop new course material and design projects to prepare students for transportation electrification and smart grid challenges.

Main Findings: The new results from this project have achieved these goals and significantly advanced our understanding and capability in managing battery networks. Our main findings include: (1) We have developed new multi-objective optimization methods for battery charge management. Problem formulation, nonlinear battery models, optimization indices, algorithms, convergence properties, and numerical solutions were investigated and established. (2) We have introduced a new framework of hybrid observation and control for battery networks. The new hybrid control strategies control both battery network structures (discrete events) and charge/discharge current (analog control) to achieve desired SOC management. (3) We have developed new tools for characterizing the entire battery system from its components by using rigorous statistical analysis methods. We have analyzed estimation of system-level capacity, stored energy, and power loss, and the estimation reliability.  (4) We have developed discrete-event on-line fault diagnosis strategies with significant computational advantages. (5) We have developed new course materials in our electric vehicle and renewable energy courses to facilitate integrated research-education development and enhance student experience in new technologies.

Intellectual merits:  This project has fundamentally advanced our knowledge on battery network management methodologies and algorithms. (1) By introducing new hybrid control strategies, battery networks’ observability and controllability can be critically improved. Such conditions are essential for any estimation and control methods in managing battery networks. (2) The hybrid control methods employ real-time data to perform integrated parameter estimation, state estimation, and control to achieve coordinated battery network management. As such, they can be used to manage battery networks under time-varying environment, changing operating conditions, and battery aging.  (3) Our new hybrid methodologies provide methods and guidelines for active system reconfiguration and adaptation in real-time operation. By using real-time hardware reconfiguration, a partially damaged battery network can be reconfigured to sustain operation. (4) Some technology aspects of our new findings have been granted a US patent for potential technology transfer. (5) Some new technologies developed in this project have been developed into new course materials in battery management systems and power systems, in the EVE (Electrical Vehicle Engineering) MS degree programs at WSU.

Broader impacts:  The hybrid methods on identification, estimation, control, diagnosis, system reconfiguration developed in this project are generic and can be broadly applied to a wide spectrum of applications. These include many networked systems such as smart grids, smart buildings, autonomous vehicles, to name only a few. Our integrated effort in combining research and education has shown impact on our educational programs by engaging students in new technologies. Reliability, sustained operation, high efficiency operation of electric-drive vehicles and battery support of renewable energy systems can potentially help market penetration of electric vehicles in the consumer market, reliable operations of battery systems in commercial and emergency operation, and advancement on energy-saving smart building technology. WSU is in the center of manufacturing and technology industry on vehicles and battery systems as well as an established workforce incubator to key battery and auto industry. Support from this project has assisted our engineering programs for workforce training, especially for under-represented student groups.
